text: These are people who certainly have not proved that they are worthy of the trust that we repose in them. As far as this job is concerned, let me also indicate that when it comes to BECE, most of the decisions are taken by the Ghana Education Service. For example, the selection of supervisors and invigilators is done by the district exams officer, he explained. His comments come in the wake of a JoyNews Hotline investigation led by GH Probe’s Francisca Enchil, which uncovered disturbing levels of collusion at examination centres.
translated: [Hei hi mite kan an ni lo, kan hriatthiam an nei lo, kan inmil tlat an ni. He job hi a kawngah chuan, kei pawh in hrilh ve mai ang, BECE chungchangah chuan, decision tam zawk chu Ghana Education Service in an la siam a, supervisor leh invigilator te thlan dan pawh district exams officer in a tih a ni, a ti. A sawi hi JoyNews Hotline in Francisca Enchil a hova an investigation a chhui chhuah, examination centre ah collusion a awm nasa hle tih an chhui chhuah hnuah a ni.]
backtranslated: [This is not a job we are not understanding, we are perfectly compatible. In this case, you can also tell me that in the case of BECE, most of the decisions are still made by the Ghana Education Service, and the selection of supervisors and supervisors is done by the district exams officer. This was after JoyNews Hotline investigated Francisca Enchil in the face of their investigation, which revealed that there was a lot of collusion in the examination centre.]

text: A variety of socioeconomic and cultural factors were identified as major barriers to accessing and utilizing MHCS. Over half of the women surveyed cited poverty, illiteracy, restrictions from their husbands, the distance to health facilities, and long queues as reasons for not using services. Additionally, over a third of the women pointed to cultural practices within their communities as a cause for delays in seeking care. These findings reveal that addressing maternal health in this region requires more than just improving clinical services; it also means tackling deeply rooted societal and personal challenges that women face daily.
translated: [Khawvela hmasawnna leh nunphung chi hrang hrangte hi MHCS a hman leh a hmang theih lohna kawng hrang hrang a ni. Nu hmeichhia te zinga pakhat chuangte chuan, harsatna lian tak tak chu, kan nghawng, kan hre lo, kan pasal ten kan tih loh, damdawi in a kalna hmun a la hniam, leh queue a la chhia te an ni. Chhunzawm zelin, nu hmeichhia te zinga pakhat chuangte chuan, an khua leh tui a nunphung chi hrang hrangte hi, damdawi in pan theih lohna kawng a ni. Heng chhinchhiahna te hi, hmeichhe hriselna kawng a hmasawnna a ngaih a, clinical service a siam that bak a ni lo, khawvela harsatna leh hmeichhe te tawrhna te a tawrhna te a tawrhna te a tawrhna te a text: Despite his shortcomings, Unoka was a talented musician. He was a tall but very thin man with a slight stoop and a mournful look, which would disappear when he was drinking or playing his flute. His happiest moments came in the months after the harvest, when the village musicians would retrieve their instruments from above the fireplace. Unoka would join them, his face filled with pure joy and peace. Sometimes, other villages would invite Unoka and his band to teach them their tunes, and they would stay for several months, sharing their music.
translated: [Unoka hian a tawrh lo mahse, a pianphung a tha hle a, a sang a vai hle a, a khum a vawng a, a hmel a nuam lo a, mahse a zuam a, a sa a phun a, a hmel a nuam a. A hlimna ber chu an raih tawh hnuah, khua pianphung mi ten an pianphung an lak chhuah hnuah a ni a, Unoka pawh an zui a, a hmel a nuam a, a tlan a. Tlangval te pawh Unoka leh a pianphung te chu an sawm a, an pianphung an zirtir a, an awm a, an pianphung an inzirtir a.]
backtranslated: [Enoch, though not suffering, was very strong and tall, and he was very tall, and he was very bedridden, and he was not very pleasant, but he was swimming, he was eating meat, he was pleasant. His greatest joy was after they had won, after the natives had taken their birthright, and after they had won, the natives took their birthright, and then Enoch followed, he was pleased, and he ran. The young men also invited Enoch and his family, and they taught them their birthright, and they lived, and they taught them their birthright.]

text: At the Derby Avenue RC Basic School and St. George’s Anglican Basic School in Accra, invigilators were captured openly demanding GH¢60 daily tokens, supervisors pocketed envelopes of GH¢400, and candidates were asked to contribute to an Aseda Offertory. John Kapi stressed that once WAEC provides feedback on such incidents, it is the responsibility of the Ghana Education Service (GES) to take decisive action. And so when these issues come up, once the feedback goes to them, we [WAEC] expect that they would react appropriately and ensure that the right action is taken against the people, he said.
translated: [Derby Avenue RC Basic School leh St. George’s Anglican Basic School, Accra-a invigilator-te chu GH¢60 daily tokens an phut chhuah thei tawh a, supervisor-te chuan GH¢400 envelope an khuh tawh a, candidate-te chu Aseda Offertory atan thehluh turin an ngen a. text: For rural communities in Ghana, especially in the Kumbungu district, access to and use of maternal healthcare services (MHCS) remain a significant challenge. This study set out to explore the specific barriers preventing women from utilizing these services and to evaluate the quality of care provided. The research adopted a mixed-methods approach, combining both quantitative and qualitative data to get a comprehensive view of the situation. This phased design involved surveying 441 pregnant and postpartum women and conducting interviews with 20 healthcare providers. A facility checklist was also used to assess the state of clinics, including the availability of essential drugs and equipment.
translated: [Ghana ram chhunga khaw hrang hrang, Kumbungu district a cheng te phei chuan, nu nau enkawlna leh hriselna (MHCS) kawng a kal leh a hmanna hi a buaithlak tak zet a. He study hian nu nau hriselna leh enkawlna a kal thei lohna kawng hrang hrangte leh hriselna leh enkawlna a pe theih dan zirchiang tur a ni. He research hian mixed-methods approach a hmangin, data hrang hrangte a thlengin, harsatna chi hrang hrangte a hmu theih nan a hmang. He design phase hian nu nau 441 leh nu nau tawh te survey na leh healthcare providers 20 te interview na a nei a, facility checklist a hmangin clinic hrang hrangte dinhmun, a bikin essential drugs leh equipment a awm dan te a endik bawk.]
backtranslated: [In the rural areas of Kumbungu district in Ghana, access to and use of maternity care and health services (MHCS) is a major issue. The study aims to investigate the different ways that access to maternity care and health services is reduced and how health services can be provided. The research uses a mixed-methods approach, access to a variety of data sources, and a variety of challenges. The design phase includes interviews with 441 pregnant and lactating mothers and 20 healthcare providers, and a checklist to assess the status of various clinics, their essential drugs and equipment.]

text: Okonkwo was a man of great renown throughout his nine villages and even beyond, a fame built entirely on his own remarkable achievements. At just eighteen years old, he brought honor to his village by defeating Amalinze the Cat, a legendary wrestler who had been undefeated for seven years. Amalinze earned his nickname because his back never once touched the earth. The old men of the village considered Okonkwo's victory one of the fiercest fights they had ever seen.
translated: [Okonkwo chu a ni a, a khawvel pum a hmingthang hle a ni. A khaw chhunga mi te leh a khaw chhunga mi te pawh a hming an hre hle. A hmingthang hi a nihna a\anga a lo chhuak a ni. Kum 18 a nihin, a khaw a hmingthang tura a lo chhuah a, Amalinze the Cat, a khawvel pum a hmingthang wrestler a, kum 7 chhung a\anga a tlawm lo chu a hneh a. Amalinze chu a hming a\anga a lo chhuak a ni, a back a\anga a lo chhuak a ni, a back a\anga a lo chhuak a ni. A khaw a\anga mi upa te chuan Okonkwo a\anga a lo chhuah a, a khaw a\anga a lo chhuah a, a khaw a\anga a lo chhuah a, a khaw a\anga a lo chhuah a ni.]
backtranslated: [Okonkwo is a very famous person in the world. His name is well known to the people of his town and the people of his town. His fame comes from his personality. When he was 18, he came to his town to be famous, and he defeated Amalinze the Cat, his world-famous wrestler, who had not visited him for 7 years. Amalinze came from his name, his back, his back. The elders of his town came from Okonkwo, his back, his back, his back.]

text: Muntaka assured the committee of full logistical and secretariat support from the Ministry and urged them to partner with civil society organizations, development partners, and faith-based institutions in carrying out their work. He described the task as heavy but honorable, stressing that the people of Gbenyiri and surrounding communities were looking up to the committee as instruments of peace, reconciliation, and healing.
translated: [Muntaka chuan committee-te hnenah Ministry atangin logistical leh secretariat support pum pui a pe dawn tih a hrilh a, an hna thawhna-ah civil society organization, development partner leh faith-based institution-te nena partnership nei turin a ngen a. Hna hi a tawp tawp a, mahse ropui a ni tih a sawi a, Gbenyiri leh a chhehvel khua te mipui-te chu committee-te hi remna, insum theihna leh chhandamna instrument-te angin an ngai a ni tih a sawi a.]
backtranslated: [Muntaka told the committees that he would provide full logistical and secretariat support from the Ministry and asked them to partner with civil society organizations, development partners and faith-based institutions in their work. He said the work was over, but it was great, and that the people of Gbenyiri and the surrounding villages saw the committees as instruments of peace, self-reliance and salvation.]

text: The study also shed light on significant facility-based challenges that compromise the quality of care. A key issue was the inadequate number of midwives, which likely contributes to the long queues women reported. Additionally, the absence of essential equipment and drugs was a major problem. For example, health service providers specifically recommended a greater number of trained midwives and the provision of critical logistics like ultrasound machines and proper delivery equipment to ensure effective and high-quality care.
translated: [Chhutna hian facility-based chhinchhiahna pawimawh tak tak a tarlang a, a hnuai ah chhinchhiahna a awm bawk. Heng zinga pawimawh ber chu midwife a tam loh vang a ni a, hei hian hmeichhe te hian an report tawh angin, an in queue tlem a, a awm thei hle. Chhinchhiahna dang chu, equipment leh drug pawimawh tak tak a awm loh a ni. Chhutna hian, health service provider te chuan midwife thiam zawk leh tam zawk an mamawh a, ultrasound machine leh delivery equipment tha tak tak an mamawh bawk a, hei hian an care chu tha leh chhuanawm a awm thei nan a ni.]
backtranslated: [This table lists the most important facility-based indicators, followed by the indicators. The most important of these is the shortage of midwives, which, as women report, can lead to fewer and more frequent queues. Another indicator is the lack of essential equipment and medications. In this table, health service providers need more and more skilled midwives, and ultrasound machines and powerful delivery equipment, to provide quality and convenience in their care.]

text: Okonkwo was an imposing figure, tall and massive with a severe expression, a result of his bushy eyebrows and wide nose. His breathing was so heavy that his family could hear it from their own houses when he slept. When he walked, his heels barely touched the ground, making him seem poised to pounce on someone—which he often did. He had a slight stammer, and in moments of anger, he would resort to his fists when words failed him. He had no patience for men who were not successful, and this sentiment stemmed from his deep-seated shame for his own father.

text: The West African Examinations Council (WAEC) says officials implicated in acts of corruption during the Basic Education Certificate Examination (BECE) will be blacklisted from ever taking part in its activities again. Speaking on JoyNews’ PM Express on September 8, WAEC’s Director of Public Affairs, John Kapi, said the Council cannot continue to work with individuals who have betrayed the trust placed in them during national examinations.

text: The study found that while a high percentage of women did engage with some maternal health services—87.5% attended antenatal care (ANC), 87.3% had a skilled delivery, and 84.8% had a postnatal care (PNC) visit—the frequency of care was a concern. A little over half of the participants (53.4%) had the recommended four or more ANC visits, and nearly half (46.9%) didn't register until their second trimester. These figures highlight a gap between initial access and consistent, timely utilization of services, suggesting that women may be facing obstacles that prevent them from fully engaging with the healthcare system throughout their pregnancies.
translated: [Naupangte chu, hmeichhe tam takin nu nau dawr dan leh inenkawl dan a kaltlanga an inen a, ANC-ah 87.5% in an kal, 87.3% in an inen a, PNC-ah 84.8% in an kal a, inen kaltlanga an inen dan a zir chiang a, a harsatna a awm. Naupangte zinga 53.4% chauh in an inen kaihruai tura tih dan anga vawi 4 leh a tam zawk an inen a, 46.9% chauh in an inen hnuhnung berah an register a, hei hi hmeichhe te chu an nau laia healthcare system a an inen dan a zir chiang a, an inen dan a harsatna a awm tih a lang. ]
backtranslated: [In children, many women are screened through pregnancy and care protocols, 87.5% go to the ANC, 87.3% go to the PNC, 84.8% go to the PNC, and learn how to screen through the protocol, and have problems. Only 53.4% of children are screened 4 or more times as recommended by the protocol, and only 46.9% register at the last screening, which shows that women are screened through the healthcare system during pregnancy and have problems with their screening. ]

text: The crowd held its breath as the drums beat and the flutes sang. Amalinze was a clever opponent, but Okonkwo was just as skilled, and as slippery as a fish in water. Both men were incredibly strong, their muscles and nerves straining to the point of almost breaking. But in the end, Okonkwo emerged victorious. This monumental win was just the beginning of his legacy. Over the next twenty years, his fame spread like a wildfire, fueled by his unwavering resolve and personal triumphs.

text: The seven-member mediation committee will be chaired by Mr. Emmanuel Habuka Bombande. Other members of the committee include Alhaji Collins Dauda (MP and chair of the Committee on Lands and Natural Resource in Parliament), Rev. Father Lazarus Annyere (Chair of Savannah Regional Peace Council), Dr. Festus Aubyn (West Africa Network for Peace-building), Sylvia Hormane Noagbesenu Esq (Ag. Director of Women, Youth, Peace and Security Institute, Kofi Annan International Peacekeeping Training Center), Prof. Ramatu Alhassan and Dr. George Amoh (Ex. Sec. NPC) who will be the secretary.

NPC) te an ni a, Dr. George Amoh chu Secretary a ni dawn a ni.]
backtranslated: [Five members of the mediation committee will be appointed, Mr. Emmanuel Habuka Bombande will be the Chairman. Other members of the committee are Alhaji Collins Dauda (MP and Chairman of the Committee on Lands and Natural Resources in Parliament), Rev. Father Lazarus Annyere (Chairman of the Savannah Regional Peace Council), Dr. Festus Aubyn (West Africa Network for Peace-building), Sylvia Hormane Noagbesenu Esq (Ag. Director of Women, Youth, Peace and Security Institute, Kofi Annan International Peacekeeping Training Center), Prof. Ramatu Alhassan and Dr. George Amoh (Ex. Sec. of NPC), Dr. George Amoh will be the Secretary.]

text: To improve maternal health in the Kumbungu district, both study participants and service providers offered actionable recommendations. Women suggested focusing on public education about maternal care, enforcing free MHCS, and improving the local road network to make facilities more accessible. Providers emphasized the need for more midwives and better equipment. The study concludes that both governmental and non-governmental organizations must increase investment in maternal health and address the broader socioeconomic issues affecting women. This comprehensive approach, tackling both healthcare system deficiencies and community-level barriers, is essential for truly improving maternal health outcomes.
translated: [Kumbungu district-a nuam zawn maternal health thar chhuah nan, zirtirte leh hriatna pe theihtute pawh an lo sawi a, an lo rawtna te pawh an nei a. Nu te chuan maternal care chungchangah public education pe, MHCS a free pe leh, local road network siam that a, facility te a kal theih nan an rawtna a. Hriatna pe theihtute chuan midwife tam zawk leh equipment tha zawk an mamawh thu an sawi a. He study hian government leh non-government organization te chu maternal health ah investment tam zawk senga, nu te tana socioeconomic issue hrang hrang te pawh an ngaihtuah a ngai a ti a. Healthcare system leh community level a awm barrier te pawh tawh khawm a, maternal health outcome thar chhuah nan a pawimawh a ni.]
backtranslated: [For the development of new maternal health in Kumbungu district, educators and information providers also spoke and made recommendations. Mothers recommended public education on maternal care, free MHCS, and a local road network to improve access to facilities. Advisors said they needed more midwives and more powerful equipment. The study said that more government and non-government organizations need to consider various socioeconomic issues, including increased investment in maternal health. It is important to address barriers to maternal health outcomes, including those at the healthcare system and community level.]

text: Unoka, Okonkwo's father, had passed away ten years prior. He was a man known for his laziness and carelessness, living only for the present with no thought for the future. Any money he managed to acquire—which was a rare occurrence—he would immediately spend on palm-wine, gathering his neighbors for a celebration. He believed that to see a dead man's mouth was to see the foolishness of not eating what you had in life. Unoka was also deeply in debt, owing money to nearly every one of his neighbors.
